epigraphs.text: The line between citizen and stranger is first drawn in law, and then enforced in memory.
The most common way people give up their power is by thinking they do not have any.
Every extension of state power over the body is also a claim over the story that body may tell.

long_synopsis: Week 44 of Trump’s second term saw no single rupture, but a dense layering of moves that tightened control over bodies, borders, and archives. The Democracy Clock held at 8:11 p.m., reflecting not calm but consolidation: already elevated risks deepened without a fresh lurch. Immigration raids in Charlotte and Chicago, backed by National Guard deployments over local objections, treated sanctuary policies as defiance and ordinary presence as threat, chilling protest even as courts and city councils tried to reassert warrant requirements. A sweeping anti-trans offensive, via executive orders and guidance, stripped recognition, care, housing, prison protections, documentation, and school materials while erasing related federal data, formalizing second-class status and informational disappearance. In parallel, Congress nearly unanimously mandated release of Epstein files, only to face executive maneuvers to blunt transparency and weaponize new investigations. Across the FBI, DHS, VA, and foreign policy, loyalty, patronage, and Saudi-linked business blurred public duty with private gain, while eliminationist rhetoric against lawmakers and pressure on media normalized coercion amid pockets of civil and judicial resistance.
